Award.AwardTitle: Energy and Electron Transport in pi-Stacked Multichromophoric Assemblies: Global Dynamics from the Gas to Condensed Phase
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division, Professors Rajendra Rathore and Scott Reid of Marquette University will examine model molecular assemblies that incorporate stacked polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Such interactions are characteristic of many molecular assemblies, including those found in nature (e.g., DNA), and an understanding of the transport of electrons and energy through such assemblies is critical to develop new charge-transfer materials of increased efficiency for applications in photovoltaic devices, molecular electronics, and nanotechnology. To meet this challenge, the synthesis of carefully designed molecular assemblies is carried out, and the assemblies characterized using a variety of experimental strategies based on molecular spectroscopy, supported by computational chemistry.

Supramolecular assemblies exploit a variety of covalent and non-covalent scaffolding interactions. Of these, pi-stacking is important. The efficiency of long range charge transfer in the conducting layers of photovoltaic devices is governed not only by the intramolecular electron transport through the backbone of polymers but also by the intermolecular electron transport through bulk material, where the amorphous assembly of pi-conjugated molecules is generally randomized. As cyclophane-like aromatic dimers and their cation radicals represent the simplest fundamental units responsible for charge transport in bulk materials, the design and synthesis of modern organic materials for the emerging area of molecular electronics and nanotechnology demands a thorough understanding of electron and energy-transfer processes in carefully designed cofacially-arrayed molecules. This project addresses fundamental questions concerning the flow of energy and electron transfer in model multichromophoric systems and developes new strategies for exploiting such assemblies as light driven actuators, taking advantage of the molecular rearrangement which accompanies oxidation or electronic excitation. Examining broader impacts, this work informs the design and synthesis of next generation organic materials for applications in the area of molecular electronics and photovoltaics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Supramolecular assemblies lie beyond the molecular domain, encompassing systems made of assembled molecular components.  Such assemblies have manifold applications, and can be built using a variety of covalent and non-covalent scaffolding interactions.  Of these, perhaps none is more important than π-stacking. The efficiency of long range charge transfer in the conducting layers of photovoltaic devices is governed by not only the intramolecular electron transport through the backbone of polymers but also by the intermolecular electron transport through bulk material, where the amorphous assembly of π-conjugated molecules is generally randomized. The design and synthesis of modern organic materials for the emerging area of molecular electronics and nanotechnology demands a thorough understanding of electron and energy-transfer processes in carefully designed cofacially-arrayed molecules.  In this project, the PIs engaged in a collaborate set of highly intertwined synthetic and spectroscopic strategies to accomplish the goal of developing efficient charge-transfer materials,  which, in turn, are expected to significantly impact areas ranging from molecular electronics and nanotechnology to solar energy storage

This project focused on experimental studies, supported by theory, of the dynamics of energy and electron transfer in model π-stacked assemblies, utilizing a novel set of multichromophoric assemblies (Figure 1A). Key findings of this project include:

First experimental evidence for the diverse geometrical requirements of excimer vs. hole formation in p-stacked assemblies. Gas-phase studies compared the covalently linked F2 bichromophore with the van der Waals dimer of fluorene, i.e., (F)2. As shown in Figure 1B, ion yield curves, measured using two-color resonant ionization spectroscopy under jet-cooled conditions, show identical ionization potentials for the two dimers, indicative of similar hole stabilization. However, emission spectra (Figure 1B) reveal a significant stabilization (up to 30 kJ/mol) of the excimeric state in the covalently linked dimer. This finding, supported by extensive theoretical calculations, indicates that excimer formation requires a perfect “sandwich” overlap of the two chromophores, whereas hole stabilization is geometrically less restrictive.

Two’s company, three’s a crowd: Exciton localization in π-stacked assemblies and mechanism for exciton Transfer. Studies of the evolution of the emission spectra in the covalently linked Fn series show that spectra for n > 2 are nearly identical to that of the dimer. This surprising result suggests that the excitonic state is localized on only two subunits for all n. Theoretical studies of a model system, F9, reveal that the energetic gain from delocalization quickly saturates, while the energetic penalty due to structural reorganization increases linearly with n. Importantly, structures where the excimeric state is localized either on the end of the chain or in the middle are nearly isoenergetic, with a small barrier to their interconversion. Thus, this study identified a mechanism for exciton involving a localized exciton “hopping” along the polymer chain, illustrated schematically in Figure 1C.

Size evolution of hole delocalization in π-stacked assemblies. We examined the size evolution of hole delocalization in van der Waals clusters of fluorene (i.e., (F)n), where a range of geometries are possible, reflecting both π-stacking and C-H/π interactions, compared with the model covalently linked assemblies (Fn) . Using mass-selected two-color resonant two-photon ionization spectroscopy (2CR2PI), we measured electronic spectra and vertical ionization potentials (IPs) in the gas-phase. For both systems, an inverse size dependence (i.e., 1/n) of IP vs. cluster size was found; however, the values surprisingly fall on same line! This trend was reproduced via theory, emphasizing the important role of π-stacking, and its geometrical dependencies, in the process of hole delocalization in multichromophoric assemblies.

Broader impacts of this work include important new insights into the role of cofacility and geometrical restriction in the stabilization of hole and exciton in π-stacked assemblies. The results are relevant to the design of new D(onor)-W(ire)-A(cceptor) assemblies, where optimization of wire properties is a critical step towards optimizing charge separation and minimizing recombination.  During this project, six undergraduate students, three graduate students, one high school student, and four postdoctoral scholars have been trained in research. Four project participants were female. Two postdoctoral scholars obtained faculty positions, Marat Talipov at New Mexico State, and Neil Reilly at U Mass Boston. The PIs met with each student regularly and worked directly with students in the lab on a regular basis, thereby fostering an environment where intellectual exchange at a high level is combined with significant one-on-one interaction and mentoring. Through presentations at weekly group meetings and scientific meetings, and writing workshops, students develop as both communicators and independent practitioners of science.

Two Ph.D. dissertations and 32 publications in peer-reviewed journals resulted from the efforts of the award.
